entries.text: Create internal cloud hosting solutions within Morgan Stanley. As a contributor on our budapest-based team, you will have responsibility to contribute not only to the code, but to the design and engineering of the full PaaS systems.
entries.title: Morgan Stanley Budapest Perl developer for cloud

entries.text: There are going to be 3 courses at YAPC::EU in Granada, Spain. At one of them you can learn how to use Angular JS together with Perl Dancer. Sign up now!
entries.title: Front-end with AngularJS, Back-end with Perl Dancer and MongoDB

entries.author: graham_ollis
entries.text: Graham wanted to get Convert::Binary::C updated. But rather than fork it, or adopt it, he blogged about it about first. As a result the author, Marcus, released an update this week. This approach doesn't always have a happy ending, but it shows why it's usually the right first step.
entries.title: Convert::Binary::C anyone?

entries.author: thomas_klausner
entries.text: DOMM has released InfluxDB::LineProtocol, a generator and parser for the LineProtocol used by InfluxDB. His work recently moved from Graphite / Whisper to InfluxDB.
entries.title: Announcing InfluxDB::LineProtocol

entries.author: miguel_prz
entries.text: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.
entries.title: NICEPERL's lists

entries.author: dean_hamstead
entries.text: Dean gave a talk to Sydney.PM about Log::Log4perl.
entries.title: Getting modern with logging via Log4perl

entries.author: graham_ollis
entries.text: Graham makes the case for using Alien::Base, both for CPAN authors and system vendors. He also makes it clear that Alien::Base is actively maintained, and the team are keen to hear about issues and support both types of users.
entries.title: Alien::Base: System Integrators vs. CPAN Authors

entries.author: david_farrell
entries.text: David continues his series of infosec articles by explaining port scanning, then showing how you can build a port scanner in Perl 5.
entries.title: Port scanning with Perl

entries.author: matt_trout
entries.text: Matt sings the praises of DreamHost, both for their shared hosting and their provision of compute and storage resources for the perl-qa team.
entries.title: A Dream Within A Dream

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: The slidecast Perl tutorial has passed 148 freely available episodes. Available on YouTube or downloadable from the Perl Maven site.
entries.title: Beginner Perl Maven video course

entries.author: matt_trout
entries.text: There's been quite a bit of discussion about Perl 5.6 recently, and whether your CPAN distributions should support it. Matt presents his very pragmatic approach to supporting Perl 5.6 or not.
entries.title: On Perl 5.6

entries.author: david_golden
entries.text: In his contribution to the Perl 5.6 discussion, David's position is similar to Matt's, but he makes the observation that most 5.6 work seems to be related to smoke testing with 5.6, rather then people who are using Perl 5.6 in production.
entries.title: Why you shouldn't waste your time on Perl 5.6

entries.author: balint_szilakszi
entries.text: Bálint argues that people shouldn't support Perl 5.6, for security reasons.
entries.title: Software doesn't exist in isolation

entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: After seeing all the 5.6 disussion, I was wondering how many people are using Perl 5.6 in production? If you are, please let me know.
entries.title: Are you using Perl 5.6 in production?

entries.author: flavio_glock
entries.text: Flávio is continuing to work on his Perl 5 to Java compiler, posting both benchmark results and a brief update.
entries.title: A perl5 to Java compiler - first benchmark

entries.author: jonathan_worthington
entries.text: Jonathan had a productive week: getting multi-dimensional arrays working in the JVM (following MoarVM, which was done previously); thinking through the design for await to not take up a thread when waiting for the promise to complete; thinking about a friendly syntax for supplies; some useful MoarVM bytecode instrumentation; fixed some regexp issues; and improved some error messages. In short: "Stuff Got Done".
entries.title: This week: concurrency stuff, multi-dimensional stuff, stuff stuff…

entries.author: jeff_goff
entries.text: Jeff has released the first version of Perl::ToPerl6, a module which will convert (parts of) your code to the equivalent Perl 6 syntax. It's version 0.1, so doesn't handle everything yet. You could help with that maybe? Some lucky soul may even get it next month in the Pull Request Challenge :-)
entries.title: Perl::ToPerl6 released to CPAN

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: More than 200 people have now signed up to attend YAPC::EU this year, passing two previous conferences. And there's still a month to go. Gabor points out there are some interesting talks, if you're still thinking about it.
entries.title: YAPC::EU - over 200 participants

entries.author: karen_pauley
entries.text: Dave Mitchell recently applied for a $20k grant to allow him to continue his work on the Perl 5 core; it's now been approved, which is good news for us all.
entries.title: Dave Mitchell's grant extended

entries.author: peter_rabbitson
entries.text: Ribasushi put forward an idea for a grant project: taking the lead on writing improved documentation for DBIx::Class. He points out that this is not a minor undertaking.
entries.title: Grant idea - DBIx::Class re-documentation

entries.author: timmy_willison
entries.text: The jQuery project recently announced the first alpha release of jQuery 3. This post lists the major changes coming.
entries.title: jQuery 3.0 and jQuery Compat 3.0 Alpha Versions Released

entries.author: tomasz_nurkiewicz
entries.text: Tomasz thinks that the RESTful approach for APIs is flawed in a number of ways. Some of his arguments are about how people implement particular RESTful APIs (eg choice of JSON), but he makes plenty of valid observations. In the end though: horses for courses.
entries.title: RESTful considered harmful

entries.text: Notes from a half-day workshop at OSCON about building strong open source communities.
entries.title: A guide for community management from Jono Bacon

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: In preparation for the front-end development course at YAPC::EU, Gabor started to publish articles on using AngularJS.
entries.title: Getting started with AngularJS

header:
Perl 6 is getting more and more interest, but this week also
saw a lot of discussion about 5.6, which was first released in 2000,
the year when Perl 6 work started. The core question: should CPAN
authors (bother to) support Perl 5.6?
subject: (How) should we support Perl 5.6?
